source.author: Michael, P.W.
source.title: Eryngium
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Michael, P.W. (1999). Eryngium. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Prostrate plants with basal leaves up to 35 cm long; flowering stems and bracteoles not tinged with blue or purple; flowering heads 5–7 mm long borne on peduncles arising directly from centre of rosette and from trailing stems
Erect plants to 60 cm high with basal leaves up to 50 cm long; flowering stems and bracteoles often tinged with blue or purple; flowering heads 10–20 mm or more long, borne on erect or trailing stems

Flowering heads cylindric, mostly about 15 mm long but sometimes reaching 20 mm or more, about twice as long as wide; bracteoles between involucre and apex inconspicuous, exceeding the flowers by no more than 3 mm, often much less; basal leaves entire, cylindric, septate, occasionally with a few teeth or spines of variable length in upper portion

Flowering heads more or less ovoid, mostly about 10 mm long but reaching 15 mm and about 10 mm wide; bracteoles between involucre and apex conspicuous, often exceeding flowers by 8–15 mm; basal leaves usually deeply divided and spiny
